content.description: A sled is released from rest at Point <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mtext>A</mtext></math> on a track where friction between the sled and the track is negligible. Point <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mtext>A</mtext></math> is at a vertical position of <math alttext="y equals h sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, as shown. The sled remains in contact with the track as the sled passes through points <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mtext>B</mtext></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mtext>C</mtext></math>.
content.question: Which of the following correctly indicates how the speed of the cart depends on the vertical position <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math> of the cart after it is released?

choices.label: <math alttext="v is proportional to y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi><mo>∝</mo><mi>y</mi></math>

<math alttext="v is proportional to, open parenthesis, h sub 0, end sub, minus y, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi><mo>∝</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
<math alttext="v is proportional to the square root of y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi><mo>∝</mo><msqrt><mi>y</mi></msqrt></math>

<math alttext="v is proportional to the square root of h sub 0, end sub, minus y, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi><mo>∝</mo><msqrt><msub><mi>h</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi></msqrt></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="v is proportional to the square root of h sub 0, end sub, minus y, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi><mo>∝</mo><msqrt><msub><mi>h</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi></msqrt></math>

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
